repnme.cdata!: Laos - Third Structural Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated as
            unsatisfactory. Project sustainability is uncertain. World
            bank performance is satisfactory and Borrower performance is
            satisfactory overall. Important lessons include the
            following: First is the need to adequately reflect weak
            client capacity in the design of short-term adjustment
            support. Operations in countries such as this need to be
            more focused, limiting interventions to a few areas, but
            seeking substantive reforms likely to have high impact.
            Unfortunately, the legal development framework which
            involved substantial change was not appropriate for an
            adjustment operation. Secondly, World Bank staff need to
            focus more on the "big picture" during
            supervision. Detailed conditionalities should be seen as
            means to, not ends in, themselves. Staff should regularly
            assess the impact of measures and examine whether changes
            are needed in project design or implementation arrangements.
            Another lesson is to pay extra attention to the needs of
            small clients that usually have limited economic management
            capacity. Finally, broad support and ownership within
            government at the highest levels is important. Project
            implementation suffered because support for reforms under
            the credit was centered around a few key people; most
            decisionmakers interacted little with the Bank and did not
            understand much of the credit's objectives and details.
            Efforts should be made to understand decisionmaking and the
            political economy of reform in relatively closed societies.

repnme.cdata!:
Laos - Third Structural Adjustment Credit
            Project (SACIII)

abstracts.cdata!:
The Third Structural Adjustment Credit
            Project (SACIII) will support greater efficiency in private
            and public investment, underpinning economic growth.  By
            enhancing the efficiency of public resources management, it
            will also assist the government in shifting its focus
            towards social issues and the alleviation of poverty.  As
            with the two previous structural adjustment credits, SACIII
            will assist the government in sustaining the momentum of
            reform and undertaking more difficult structural measures.
            The basis for this project is the government's own
            adjustment program, which addresses the main factors
            limiting growth and effective poverty reduction. SACIII will
            assist the government in improving the incentive system for
            private sector development and the management of public
            resources by closely interlinking two principal components:
            1) private sector enabling environment, focusing on
            state-owned enterprise reform, the regulatory framework, and
            financial sector reform; and 2) public resources management,
            focusing on public expenditure management, civil service
            reform and the social security system.
